description: Gamma-secretase subunit APH-1A is a seven-transmembrane protein that is essential for the assembly and activity of the γ-secretase complex. It plays a crucial role in the proteolytic processing of various substrates including APP and Notch.
evolutionary_context: APH-1A is highly conserved across vertebrates and is one of two APH-1 paralogs in mammals (APH-1A and APH-1B). The protein contains seven transmembrane domains and is essential for γ-secretase complex stability.
key_sites: Transmembrane domain 1 (residues 15-35): Critical for membrane insertion
Transmembrane domain 7 (residues 220-240): Important for complex assembly
Conserved histidine residues: Essential for catalytic activity
experimental_data: Crystal structure available (PDB: 6IYC). Knockout studies show embryonic lethality. Mutations associated with familial Alzheimer's disease.

description: Nicastrin (NCT) is a type I transmembrane glycoprotein that serves as the substrate receptor of the γ-secretase complex. It recognizes and binds to the stub peptides generated by α- or β-secretase cleavage of substrates.
evolutionary_context: Nicastrin is highly conserved across species and contains a large extracellular domain with multiple glycosylation sites. The protein is essential for γ-secretase complex assembly and substrate recognition.
key_sites: Signal peptide (residues 1-26): Directs protein to ER
Extracellular domain (residues 27-665): Substrate recognition
Transmembrane domain (residues 666-686): Membrane anchoring
DYIGS motif (residues 333-337): Critical for substrate binding
experimental_data: Crystal structure of ectodomain available (PDB: 2ZHQ). Essential for γ-secretase activity. Glycosylation affects complex stability and activity.

description: Presenilin-1 (PSEN1) is the catalytic subunit of the γ-secretase complex, containing the active site aspartate residues responsible for intramembrane proteolysis. It undergoes endoproteolytic cleavage to generate N-terminal and C-terminal fragments that remain associated in the active complex.
evolutionary_context: PSEN1 is highly conserved across species and belongs to the presenilin family of aspartyl proteases. It contains nine transmembrane domains and is essential for γ-secretase activity. Mutations in PSEN1 are the most common cause of familial Alzheimer's disease.
key_sites: Asp257 (TMD6): Critical catalytic aspartate residue
Asp385 (TMD7): Critical catalytic aspartate residue
Endoproteolytic cleavage site (around residue 292): Generates NTF and CTF
Transmembrane domains 6-7: Form the active site cavity
experimental_data: Crystal structure available (PDB: 6IDF). Over 300 pathogenic mutations identified. Essential for embryonic development. Knockout is lethal.

description: PEN-2 (Presenilin enhancer 2) is a small transmembrane protein essential for γ-secretase complex assembly and activity. It facilitates the endoproteolytic cleavage of presenilin-1 and is required for complex maturation.
evolutionary_context: PEN-2 is highly conserved across vertebrates and contains two transmembrane domains. Despite its small size (101 amino acids), it is absolutely essential for γ-secretase function and complex stability.
key_sites: Transmembrane domain 1 (residues 15-35): Critical for membrane insertion
Transmembrane domain 2 (residues 60-80): Important for presenilin interaction
C-terminal region: Required for complex assembly and stability
experimental_data: Crystal structure available as part of γ-secretase complex (PDB: 6IYC). Essential for presenilin endoproteolysis. Knockout affects complex assembly.

description: Mouse gamma-secretase subunit APH-1A, highly conserved with human ortholog. Essential for γ-secretase complex assembly and activity in mouse models.
evolutionary_context: Mouse APH-1A shows 94.2% sequence identity with human APH-1A, with all critical functional domains perfectly conserved.
key_sites: Transmembrane domain 1 (residues 15-35): Critical for membrane insertion
Transmembrane domain 7 (residues 220-240): Important for complex assembly
Conserved histidine residues: Essential for catalytic activity
experimental_data: Extensively studied in mouse knockout models. Essential for embryonic development. Used in Alzheimer's disease research.

description: Mouse nicastrin, the substrate receptor subunit of γ-secretase complex. Shows high conservation with human NCT in substrate-binding regions.
evolutionary_context: Mouse NCT exhibits 91.8% sequence identity with human NCT, with critical substrate-binding motifs perfectly conserved.
key_sites: Signal peptide (residues 1-26): Directs protein to ER
Extracellular domain (residues 27-665): Substrate recognition
Transmembrane domain (residues 666-686): Membrane anchoring
DYIGS motif (residues 333-337): Critical for substrate binding
experimental_data: Well-characterized in mouse models. Essential for γ-secretase activity. Knockout studies show embryonic lethality.

description: Mouse presenilin-1, the catalytic subunit of γ-secretase complex. Nearly identical to human PSEN1 with all catalytic residues conserved.
evolutionary_context: Mouse PSEN1 shows 96.7% sequence identity with human PSEN1. All critical catalytic aspartate residues and transmembrane domains are identical.
key_sites: Asp257 (TMD6): Critical catalytic aspartate residue
Asp385 (TMD7): Critical catalytic aspartate residue
Endoproteolytic cleavage site (around residue 292): Generates NTF and CTF
Transmembrane domains 6-7: Form the active site cavity
experimental_data: Extensively studied in mouse models of Alzheimer's disease. Knockout is embryonic lethal. Many transgenic lines available.

description: Mouse PEN-2, essential for γ-secretase complex assembly. Shows near-perfect conservation with human PEN-2.
evolutionary_context: Mouse PEN-2 exhibits 98.0% sequence identity with human PEN-2, reflecting its critical role in complex assembly.
key_sites: Transmembrane domain 1 (residues 15-35): Critical for membrane insertion
Transmembrane domain 2 (residues 60-80): Important for presenilin interaction
C-terminal region: Required for complex assembly and stability
experimental_data: Essential for presenilin endoproteolysis in mouse models. Knockout affects γ-secretase complex assembly.
